chapter4.title: Jnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga (The Yoga of Knowledge and Renunciation of Action)
chapter4.description: In Chapter 4, Krishna reveals the eternal nature of his teachings, explaining how he imparts divine knowledge across ages. He elaborates on the integration of action (Karma Yoga), knowledge (Jnana Yoga), and renunciation, emphasizing that selfless action performed with wisdom leads to liberation. Krishna describes various forms of sacrifice and the supremacy of knowledge in attaining freedom from material bondage.

slok1.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्। विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत्।।4.1।।
slok1.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca imaṁ vivasvate yogaṁ proktavān aham avyayam, vivasvān manave prāha manur ikṣvākave ’bravīt
slok1.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: I taught this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvan (the Sun-god), Vivasvan taught it to Manu, and Manu taught it to Ikshvaku.
slok1.explanation: Krishna begins Chapter 4 by revealing the ancient lineage of the Yoga he teaches, emphasizing its eternal and imperishable nature. He first imparted it to Vivasvan, who passed it to Manu (the progenitor of humanity), and Manu to Ikshvaku (a king of the solar dynasty). This sloka establishes the divine origin and timeless relevance of Krishna’s teachings, assuring Arjuna of their authenticity and inspiring trust in the path of Yoga, which integrates action and knowledge.

slok2.sanskrit: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः। स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप।।4.2।।
slok2.transliteration: evaṁ paramparā-prāptam imaṁ rājarṣayo viduḥ, sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ parantapa
slok2.meaning: Thus, this Yoga was known by the royal sages through tradition. But, O scorcher of foes, it was lost over a long period of time.
slok2.explanation: Krishna explains that the knowledge of Yoga was traditionally passed down through royal sages (rajarshis), who combined spiritual wisdom with kingly duties. However, due to the passage of time, this knowledge was lost or diluted. This sloka highlights the cyclical nature of divine wisdom, which becomes obscured in materialistic ages, setting the context for Krishna’s reintroduction of the teaching to Arjuna, reinforcing its importance for spiritual revival.

slok3.sanskrit: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः। भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम्।।4.3।।
slok3.transliteration: sa evāyaṁ mayā te ’dya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ, bhakto ’si me sakhā ceti rahasyaṁ hy etad uttamam
slok3.meaning: That same ancient Yoga I have taught you today, for you are My devotee and friend. This is a supreme secret.
slok3.explanation: Krishna declares that he is now imparting the same ancient Yoga to Arjuna because of Arjuna’s devotion and friendship. The teaching is described as a ‘supreme secret’ due to its profound spiritual value, accessible only to those with sincerity. This sloka underscores the personal bond between Krishna and Arjuna, emphasizing that divine wisdom is shared with those who are receptive, preparing Arjuna to embrace the path of selfless action and knowledge.

slok4.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः। कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति।।4.4।।
slok4.transliteration: arjuna uvāca aparaṁ bhavato janma paraṁ janma vivasvataḥ, katham etad vijānīyāṁ tvam ādau proktavān iti
slok4.meaning: Arjuna said: Your birth is recent, while Vivasvan’s birth was long ago. How am I to understand that You taught this in the beginning?
slok4.explanation: Arjuna, puzzled by Krishna’s claim of teaching Vivasvan in ancient times, questions how Krishna, born recently, could have done so. This sloka reflects Arjuna’s logical doubt, stemming from his perception of Krishna as a human. It sets the stage for Krishna to reveal his divine nature, deepening Arjuna’s understanding of Krishna’s eternal existence and the timelessness of his teachings.

slok5.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन। तान्यहं वेद सर्वं न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप।।4.5।।
slok5.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca bahūni me vyatītāni janmāni tava cārjuna, tāny ahaṁ veda sarvaṁ na tvaṁ vettha parantapa
slok5.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: Many births of Mine and yours have passed, O Arjuna. I know them all, but you do not, O scorcher of foes.
slok5.explanation: Krishna reveals his divine omniscience, stating that both he and Arjuna have had numerous past lives, but only Krishna, as the Supreme Lord, remembers them. This sloka introduces Krishna’s divine nature, distinguishing him from ordinary beings bound by ignorance. It reassures Arjuna of Krishna’s authority, encouraging trust in his teachings on Yoga and the eternal soul.

slok6.sanskrit: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्। प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय सम्भवाम्यात्ममायया।।4.6।।
slok6.transliteration: ajo ’pi sann avyayātmā bhūtānām īśvaro ’pi san, prakṛtiṁ svām adhiṣṭhāya sambhavāmy ātma-māyayā
slok6.meaning: Though I am unborn and imperishable, and the Lord of all beings, I manifest by My own power (Maya), controlling My own nature.
slok6.explanation: Krishna explains his divine incarnation: despite being unborn and eternal, he takes birth through his own Maya (divine power), controlling material nature. As the Lord of all, his incarnations are willful, not bound by karma. This sloka clarifies Krishna’s transcendental nature, deepening Arjuna’s faith and contextualizing the Yoga teachings as divine wisdom from the Supreme.

slok7.sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्।।4.7।।
slok7.transliteration: yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata, abhyutthānam adharmasya tadātmānaṁ sṛjāmy aham
slok7.meaning: Whenever there is a decline in righteousness and a rise in unrighteousness, O Bharata, I manifest Myself.
slok7.explanation: Krishna describes the purpose of his incarnations: to restore dharma (righteousness) when it declines and adharma (unrighteousness) prevails. This sloka highlights Krishna’s role as the protector of cosmic order, reassuring Arjuna that the battle against adharma is divinely sanctioned. It aligns with Karma Yoga, as Arjuna’s fight is part of this divine mission to uphold righteousness.

slok8.sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्। धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे।।4.8।।
slok8.transliteration: paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṁ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām, dharma-saṁsthāpanārthāya sambhavāmi yuge yuge
slok8.meaning: To protect the righteous, destroy the wicked, and establish dharma, I manifest in every age.
slok8.explanation: Krishna elaborates on his mission: to safeguard the virtuous, eliminate evildoers, and reestablish dharma. His recurring incarnations ensure the preservation of righteousness across ages. This sloka inspires Arjuna to view his role in the war as aligned with Krishna’s divine purpose, reinforcing the moral justification for fighting and the importance of selfless action in Karma Yoga.

slok9.sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः। त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन।।4.9।।
slok9.transliteration: janma karma ca me divyam evaṁ yo vetti tattvataḥ, tyaktvā dehaṁ punar janma naiti mām eti so ’rjuna
slok9.meaning: One who truly knows My divine birth and actions, O Arjuna, upon leaving the body, does not take rebirth but attains Me.
slok9.explanation: Krishna promises that understanding the divine nature of his incarnations and actions leads to liberation. Such a person transcends the cycle of birth and death, attaining Krishna’s divine abode. This sloka emphasizes the transformative power of spiritual knowledge (Jnana), encouraging Arjuna to deepen his understanding and devotion, integrating knowledge with action for liberation.

slok10.sanskrit: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः। बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः।।4.10।।
slok10.transliteration: vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhā man-mayā mām upāśritāḥ, bahavo jñāna-tapasā pūtā mad-bhāvam āgatāḥ
slok10.meaning: Freed from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me, taking refuge in Me, many, purified by the austerity of knowledge, have attained My state.
slok10.explanation: Krishna describes the path to liberation: devotees who overcome attachment, fear, and anger, immerse themselves in Krishna, and purify their minds through knowledge attain his divine nature. This sloka highlights the synergy of devotion (Bhakti), knowledge (Jnana), and disciplined action, inspiring Arjuna to pursue these qualities to achieve spiritual union with Krishna.

slok11.sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ति तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ति मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः।।4.11।।
slok11.transliteration: ye yathā māṁ prapadyanti tāṁs tathaiva bhajāmy aham, mama vartmānuvartanti manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ
slok11.meaning: As people surrender to Me, I reciprocate with them accordingly. All follow My path in every way, O Partha.
slok11.explanation: Krishna assures that he responds to devotees based on their approach to him, whether through devotion, knowledge, or action. All paths ultimately lead to him, as humanity follows his divine framework. This sloka emphasizes Krishna’s impartiality and the universality of spiritual paths, encouraging Arjuna to surrender through Karma Yoga, confident of divine support.

slok12.sanskrit: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः। क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा।।4.12।।
slok12.transliteration: kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṁ siddhiṁ yajanti iha devatāḥ, kṣipraṁ hi mānuṣe loke siddhir bhavati karma-jā
slok12.meaning: Desiring success in actions, people in this world worship the gods. Indeed, success from actions comes quickly in the human realm.
slok12.explanation: Krishna observes that people often perform rituals to worship deities for material success, which yields quick results in the human world. However, such actions bind them to the material realm. This sloka contrasts material pursuits with the liberating path of Karma Yoga, urging Arjuna to act selflessly for spiritual growth rather than temporary gains.

slok13.sanskrit: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः। तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम्।।4.13।।
slok13.transliteration: cātur-varṇyaṁ mayā sṛṣṭaṁ guṇa-karma-vibhāgaśaḥ, tasya kartāram api māṁ viddhy akartāram avyayam
slok13.meaning: The fourfold caste system was created by Me based on qualities and actions. Though I am its creator, know Me as the non-doer, imperishable.
slok13.explanation: Krishna explains that he created the varna system (Brahmana, Kshatriya, Vaishya, Shudra) based on individuals’ qualities (gunas) and actions (karma), not birth. As the creator, he remains detached and unchanging, unaffected by actions. This sloka clarifies the divine origin of social order, urging Arjuna to fulfill his Kshatriya duty without attachment, aligning with Karma Yoga’s principle of non-doership.

slok14.sanskrit: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा। इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते।।4.14।।
slok14.transliteration: na māṁ karmāṇi limpanti na me karma-phale spṛhā, iti māṁ yo ’bhijānanāti karmabhir na sa badhyate
slok14.meaning: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I desire their fruits. One who knows Me thus is not bound by actions.
slok14.explanation: Krishna declares that as the Supreme Lord, he is untouched by actions and their results, free from desire. Those who understand this divine nature are also freed from karmic bondage. This sloka emphasizes the importance of realizing God’s transcendence, inspiring Arjuna to perform actions without attachment, mirroring Krishna’s detachment in Karma Yoga.

slok15.sanskrit: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः। कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम्।।4.15।।
slok15.transliteration: evaṁ jñātvā kṛtaṁ karma pūrvair api mumukṣubhiḥ, kuru karmaiva tasmāt tvaṁ pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṁ kṛtam
slok15.meaning: Knowing this, ancient seekers of liberation performed actions. Therefore, do your duty, as the ancients did in the past.
slok15.explanation: Krishna cites the example of past liberated souls who performed actions with knowledge of divine detachment. He urges Arjuna to follow their precedent by fulfilling his duties. This sloka connects historical wisdom with Arjuna’s present, reinforcing that Karma Yoga, practiced with understanding, is a proven path to liberation, motivating him to fight.

slok16.sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः। तत्कर्म त्वं प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्।।4.16।।
slok16.transliteration: kiṁ karma kim akarmeti kavayo ’py atra mohitāḥ, tat karma tvaṁ pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvā mokṣyase ’śubhāt
slok16.meaning: Even the wise are confused about what is action and what is inaction. I will explain to you that action, knowing which you will be freed from evil.
slok16.explanation: Krishna acknowledges the complexity of distinguishing between action and inaction, which confuses even scholars. He promises to clarify this, offering knowledge that liberates from negative consequences. This sloka sets the stage for Krishna’s discourse on the nature of action, preparing Arjuna to understand Karma Yoga’s nuances and act wisely in the battle.

slok17.sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः। अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः।।4.17।।
slok17.transliteration: karmaṇo hy api boddhavyaṁ boddhavyaṁ ca vikarmaṇaḥ, akarmaṇaś ca boddhavyaṁ gahanā karmaṇo gatiḥ
slok17.meaning: One must understand the nature of action, forbidden action, and inaction, for the path of action is profound and mysterious.
slok17.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the need to comprehend three types of action: prescribed action (karma), forbidden action (vikarma), and inaction (akarma). The complexity of action’s consequences makes this understanding essential. This sloka underscores the depth of Karma Yoga, urging Arjuna to gain clarity to perform his duties correctly, avoiding pitfalls and achieving spiritual progress.

slok18.sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः। स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्।।4.18।।
slok18.transliteration: karmaṇy akarma yaḥ paśyed akarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ, sa buddhimān manuṣyeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsna-karma-kṛt
slok18.meaning: One who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is wise among men. Such a person is a Yogi and performs all actions.
slok18.explanation: Krishna defines true wisdom as perceiving inaction (the soul’s non-doership) in action and action (duty) in inaction (detachment). Such a person, a true Yogi, performs all duties with spiritual insight, free from attachment. This profound sloka encapsulates Karma Yoga’s essence, guiding Arjuna to act with the understanding that the soul remains untouched by material actions.

slok19.sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः। ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः।।4.19।।
slok19.transliteration: yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ, jñānāgni-dagdha-karmāṇaṁ tam āhuḥ paṇḍitaṁ budhāḥ
slok19.meaning: One whose every undertaking is free from desire and motive, whose actions are burned in the fire of knowledge, is called a sage by the wise.
slok19.explanation: Krishna describes a wise person whose actions are devoid of selfish desires and motives, purified by the fire of knowledge. Such a person’s karma does not bind them, as it is consumed by wisdom. This sloka highlights the liberating power of Jnana in Karma Yoga, encouraging Arjuna to perform his warrior duties with knowledge and detachment to avoid karmic bondage.

slok20.sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः। कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः।।4.20।।
slok20.transliteration: tyaktvā karma-phalāsaṅgaṁ nitya-tṛpto nirāśrayaḥ, karmaṇy abhipravṛtto ’pi naiva kiñcit karoti saḥ
slok20.meaning: Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of action, ever content, and dependent on nothing, such a person, though engaged in action, does nothing.
slok20.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who renounces attachment to results, remains content, and relies on the self alone is not bound by actions, despite performing them. This sloka emphasizes the principle of non-doership in Karma Yoga, where actions performed with detachment do not generate karma, urging Arjuna to fight with inner contentment and freedom from external dependencies.

slok21.sanskrit: निराशीर्वियतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः। शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्।।4.21।।
slok21.transliteration: nirāśīr yata-cittātmā tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ, śārīraṁ kevalaṁ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣam
slok21.meaning: Free from desires, with a controlled mind and self, relinquishing all possessions, one who performs only bodily actions incurs no sin.
slok21.explanation: Krishna describes a person who acts without desire, with a disciplined mind, and without attachment to possessions, performing only essential physical actions (e.g., for survival). Such actions do not incur sin or karmic consequences. This sloka reinforces Karma Yoga’s focus on minimal, selfless action, guiding Arjuna to fight as a duty without personal motives, avoiding spiritual impurity.

slok22.sanskrit: यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः। समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते।।4.22।।
slok22.transliteration: yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ, samaḥ siddhāvasiddhau ca kṛtvāpi na nibadhyate
slok22.meaning: Content with whatever comes unasked, beyond dualities, free from envy, equipoised in success and failure, such a person is not bound though acting.
slok22.explanation: Krishna portrays a liberated soul who is satisfied with spontaneous gains, unaffected by dualities (e.g., pleasure-pain), free from jealousy, and balanced in outcomes. Such a person’s actions do not bind them. This sloka highlights equanimity and contentment in Karma Yoga, encouraging Arjuna to fight with a balanced mind, free from attachment to results, to achieve liberation.

slok23.sanskrit: गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः। यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयति।।4.23।।
slok23.transliteration: gata-saṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthita-cetasaḥ, yajñāyācarataḥ karma samagraṁ pravilīyati
slok23.meaning: For one who is detached, liberated, with a mind established in knowledge, acting for the sake of sacrifice, all actions dissolve entirely.
slok23.explanation: Krishna explains that a liberated person, free from attachment and rooted in knowledge, performs actions as a sacrifice (yajna), and their karma dissolves, leaving no residue. This sloka emphasizes that selfless actions, offered to the divine, do not bind the soul, urging Arjuna to dedicate his warrior duties as a sacrificial offering to achieve spiritual freedom.

slok24.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्। ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना।।4.24।।
slok24.transliteration: brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma havir brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam, brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma-samādhinā
slok24.meaning: The act of offering is Brahman, the oblation is Brahman, offered by Brahman into the fire of Brahman. Brahman alone is to be reached by one absorbed in action as Brahman.
slok24.explanation: Krishna describes a profound vision where every aspect of a sacrifice—offering, oblation, fire, and performer—is Brahman (the ultimate reality). One who perceives all actions as Brahman attains Brahman. This sloka elevates Karma Yoga to a metaphysical level, urging Arjuna to see his actions in battle as part of the divine, fostering a spiritual perspective that leads to liberation.

slok25.sanskrit: दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते। ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति।।4.25।।
slok25.transliteration: daivam evāpare yajñaṁ yoginaḥ paryupāsate, brahmāgnāv apare yajñaṁ yajñenaivopajuhvati
slok25.meaning: Some Yogis perform sacrifices to the gods, while others offer the sacrifice itself into the fire of Brahman through sacrifice.
slok25.explanation: Krishna introduces various forms of sacrifice: some Yogis worship deities through rituals, while others offer their actions into the fire of Brahman, treating action itself as a sacrifice. This sloka illustrates the diversity of spiritual practices, encouraging Arjuna to view his warrior duties as a sacrificial offering, aligning with Karma Yoga’s principle of selfless action.

slok26.sanskrit: श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संनादति मनोगतान्। विषयान्प्राणयन्त्यन्ये यज्ञं सर्वं इन्द्रियाग्निषु।।4.26।।
slok26.transliteration: śrotrādīnīndriyāṇy anye saṁyamati mano-gatān, viṣayān prāṇayanty anye yajñaṁ sarvaṁ indriyāgniṣu
slok26.meaning: Some offer the senses like hearing into the fire of restraint, while others offer sense objects into the fire of the senses.
slok26.explanation: Krishna describes advanced Yogis who practice sensory control as a sacrifice: some restrain senses (e.g., hearing) through discipline, while others offer sense objects (e.g., sounds) into the senses, treating them as sacrificial fires. This sloka highlights the internalization of sacrifice, urging Arjuna to discipline his senses to perform duties with focus, integrating Jnana and Karma Yoga.

slok27.sanskrit: सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यति। सर्वं कर्माखिलं यज्ञे यज्ञेनैव समाप्यति।।4.27।।
slok27.transliteration: sarvaṁ karmākhilaṁ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyati, sarvaṁ karmākhilaṁ yajñe yajñenaiva samāpyati
slok27.meaning: All actions, O Partha, culminate in knowledge. All actions are perfected in sacrifice through sacrifice itself.
slok27.explanation: Krishna explains that all actions, when performed with wisdom, lead to knowledge, and all actions are perfected when offered as sacrifices. This sloka underscores the synergy of knowledge and action, encouraging Arjuna to perform his warrior duties as a sacrifice, with the understanding that such actions cultivate spiritual wisdom, leading to liberation.

slok28.sanskrit: द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे। स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतीनां संनादति व्रतिनाम्।।4.28।।
slok28.transliteration: dravya-yajñās tapo-yajñā yoga-yajñās tathāpare, svādhyāya-jñāna-yajñāś ca yatīnāṁ saṁyamati vratinām
slok28.meaning: Some offer material sacrifices, some offer austerity, some offer Yoga, and others, the disciplined ascetics, offer the sacrifice of self-study and knowledge.
slok28.explanation: Krishna lists various forms of sacrifice: material offerings, austerities, Yoga practices, and the study of scriptures or pursuit of knowledge. Each is performed by disciplined practitioners. This sloka broadens the concept of sacrifice, encouraging Arjuna to view his battlefield actions as a form of sacrifice, aligning with the diverse paths of Karma and Jnana Yoga.

slok29.sanskrit: अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे। प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः।।4.29।।
slok29.transliteration: apāne juhvati prāṇaṁ prāṇe ’pānaṁ tathāpare, prāṇa-apāna-gatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāma-parāyaṇāḥ
slok29.meaning: Some offer the outgoing breath into the incoming, and others the incoming into the outgoing, restraining both through breath control (pranayama).
slok29.explanation: Krishna describes the practice of pranayama (breath control) as a sacrifice, where Yogis regulate the prana (outgoing breath) and apana (incoming breath), balancing vital energies. This sloka highlights the advanced yogic practice of internal sacrifice, illustrating the depth of spiritual discipline. For Arjuna, it suggests that disciplined action, like breath control, can purify the mind for selfless duty.

slok30.sanskrit: अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति। सर्वंऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः।।4.30।।
slok30.transliteration: apare niyatāhārāḥ prāṇān prāṇeṣu juhvati, sarvaṁ ’py ete yajña-vido yajña-kṣapita-kalmaṣāḥ
slok30.meaning: Others, with regulated diet, offer the vital forces into the vital forces. All these knowers of sacrifice have their sins destroyed by sacrifice.
slok30.explanation: Krishna mentions Yogis who practice dietary discipline, offering their life forces (prana) as a sacrifice within themselves. All such practitioners, understanding the essence of sacrifice, purify their sins through these acts. This sloka emphasizes the cleansing power of sacrifice, encouraging Arjuna to perform his duties as a sacrificial act to purify his mind and achieve spiritual clarity.

slok31.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम्। नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम।।4.31।।
slok31.transliteration: yajña-śiṣṭāmṛta-bhujo yānti brahma sanātanam, nāyaṁ loko ’sty ayajñasya kuto ’nyaḥ kurusattama
slok31.meaning: Those who partake of the nectar of sacrifice’s remnants attain the eternal Brahman. This world is not for the non-sacrificer, how then the next, O best of the Kurus?
slok31.explanation: Krishna states that those who consume the ‘nectar’ (spiritual benefits) of sacrifice attain Brahman. Without sacrifice, one cannot prosper in this world or the next. This sloka underscores the necessity of sacrificial action for spiritual and material well-being, urging Arjuna to view his warrior duties as a sacrifice to achieve eternal liberation.

slok32.sanskrit: एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे। कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे।।4.32।।
slok32.transliteration: evaṁ bahu-vidhā yajñā vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe, karma-jān viddhi tān sarvān evaṁ jñātvā vimokṣyase
slok32.meaning: Thus, various sacrifices are spread through the mouth of Brahman (Vedas). Know them all to be born of action. Knowing this, you will be liberated.
slok32.explanation: Krishna summarizes that the Vedas describe numerous forms of sacrifice, all rooted in action. Understanding their basis in karma leads to liberation. This sloka connects Vedic sacrifices to Karma Yoga, encouraging Arjuna to perform his actions with this knowledge, ensuring his duties lead to spiritual freedom rather than bondage.

slok33.sanskrit: श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप। सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यति।।4.33।।
slok33.transliteration: śreyān dravya-mayād yajñāj jñāna-yajñaḥ parantapa, sarvaṁ karmākhilaṁ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyati
slok33.meaning: O scorcher of foes, the sacrifice of knowledge is superior to material sacrifices. All actions, O Partha, culminate in knowledge.
slok33.explanation: Krishna declares that the sacrifice of knowledge (Jnana Yajna) surpasses material sacrifices, as all actions ultimately lead to wisdom. This sloka elevates Jnana Yoga, emphasizing that true understanding purifies and liberates. For Arjuna, it suggests that performing duties with knowledge of their spiritual purpose is superior, guiding him toward liberation through enlightened action.

slok34.sanskrit: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया। उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः।।4.34।।
slok34.transliteration: tad viddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā, upadekṣyanti te jñānaṁ jñāninas tattva-darśinaḥ
slok34.meaning: Know that by prostrating, questioning, and serving, the wise who have realized the truth will impart knowledge to you.
slok34.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to seek knowledge from realized sages through humility (prostration), inquiry (questioning), and service. Such teachers, who perceive the truth, will share liberating wisdom. This sloka emphasizes the importance of a guru in spiritual growth, encouraging Arjuna to learn from Krishna’s teachings with a receptive, humble attitude to master Karma and Jnana Yoga.

slok35.sanskrit: यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव। येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि।।4.35।।
slok35.transliteration: yaj jñātvā na punar moham evaṁ yāsyasi pāṇḍava, yena bhūtāny aśeṣeṇa drakṣyasy ātmany atho mayi
slok35.meaning: Having known this, O Pandava, you will not fall into delusion again. By this, you will see all beings in your self and also in Me.
slok35.explanation: Krishna promises that true knowledge will dispel Arjuna’s delusion permanently, enabling him to perceive all beings as part of the self and Krishna. This sloka highlights the unifying vision of Jnana Yoga, where knowledge reveals the interconnectedness of all existence. It inspires Arjuna to pursue this wisdom through his duties, achieving spiritual clarity and unity with the divine.

slok36.sanskrit: अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः। सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि।।4.36।।
slok36.transliteration: api ced asi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpa-kṛttamaḥ, sarvaṁ jñāna-plavenaiva vṛjinaṁ santariṣyasi
slok36.meaning: Even if you are the most sinful of all sinners, you will cross over all sin by the boat of knowledge.
slok36.explanation: Krishna assures that knowledge acts like a boat, enabling even the greatest sinner to overcome sin and cross the ocean of material existence. This sloka underscores the redemptive power of Jnana, offering hope to Arjuna that his actions, performed with wisdom, will purify him, reinforcing the transformative potential of Karma Yoga guided by knowledge.

slok37.sanskrit: यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन। ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा।।4.37।।
slok37.transliteration: yathaidhāṁsi samiddho ’gnir bhasmasāt kurute ’rjuna, jñānāgniḥ sarva-karmāṇi bhasmasāt kurute tathā
slok37.meaning: As a blazing fire reduces fuel to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ashes.
slok37.explanation: Krishna compares knowledge to a fire that burns all karma to ashes, liberating the soul from bondage. This sloka emphasizes the purifying power of Jnana, which destroys the binding effects of actions. It encourages Arjuna to perform his warrior duties with the fire of knowledge, ensuring his actions lead to liberation rather than entanglement.

slok38.sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते। तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति।।4.38।।
slok38.transliteration: na hi jñānena sadṛśaṁ pavitram iha vidyate, tat svayaṁ yoga-saṁsiddhaḥ kālenātmani vindati
slok38.meaning: Indeed, there is nothing as purifying as knowledge in this world. One perfected in Yoga finds it within the self in time.
slok38.explanation: Krishna declares knowledge as the ultimate purifier, attainable through the practice of Yoga over time. This sloka elevates Jnana as the key to spiritual purity, promising Arjuna that consistent practice of Karma Yoga will lead to self-realized knowledge, cleansing his mind and guiding him toward liberation.

slok39.sanskrit: श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संनादितेन्द्रियः। ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति।।4.39।।
slok39.transliteration: śraddhāvān labhate jñānaṁ tat-paraḥ saṁyatendriyaḥ, jñānaṁ labdhvā parāṁ śāntim acireṇādhigacchati
slok39.meaning: One who is faithful, devoted, and has controlled senses attains knowledge. Having attained knowledge, one quickly achieves supreme peace.
slok39.explanation: Krishna outlines the prerequisites for knowledge: faith (shraddha), dedication, and sense control. Such a person attains knowledge, leading to supreme peace. This sloka emphasizes the role of discipline and devotion in Jnana Yoga, encouraging Arjuna to approach his duties with faith and restraint to realize knowledge and attain lasting peace.

slok40.sanskrit: अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति। नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः।।4.40।।
slok40.transliteration: ajñaś cāśraddhadhānaś ca saṁśayātmā vinaśyati, nāyaṁ loko ’sti na paro na sukhaṁ saṁśayātmanaḥ
slok40.meaning: The ignorant, faithless, and doubting soul perishes. For the doubting person, there is neither this world, nor the next, nor happiness.
slok40.explanation: Krishna warns that ignorance, lack of faith, and doubt lead to spiritual ruin, depriving one of success in this world, the next, and happiness. This sloka highlights the destructive nature of doubt, urging Arjuna to embrace Krishna’s teachings with confidence and clarity, ensuring his actions in Karma Yoga lead to spiritual fulfillment.

slok41.sanskrit: योगसंनादितकर्माणं ज्ञानसञ्छिन्नसंशयम्। आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय।।4.41।।
slok41.transliteration: yoga-saṁnyāsita-karmāṇaṁ jñāna-sañchinna-saṁśayam, ātmavantaṁ na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya
slok41.meaning: O Dhananjaya, one who has renounced actions through Yoga, whose doubts are cut by knowledge, and who is self-possessed, is not bound by actions.
slok41.explanation: Krishna assures that a person who dedicates actions to Yoga, resolves doubts through knowledge, and is anchored in the self is free from karmic bondage. This sloka integrates Karma and Jnana Yoga, encouraging Arjuna to perform his warrior duties with wisdom and detachment, ensuring liberation from the binding effects of action.

slok42.sanskrit: तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः। छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत।।4.42।।
slok42.transliteration: tasmād ajñāna-sambhūtaṁ hṛt-sthaṁ jñānāsinātmanaḥ, chittvainaṁ saṁśayaṁ yogam ātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata
slok42.meaning: Therefore, with the sword of knowledge, cut asunder the doubt born of ignorance in your heart. Take refuge in Yoga and arise, O Bharata.
slok42.explanation: Krishna concludes Chapter 4 by urging Arjuna to dispel his doubts, rooted in ignorance, with the sword of knowledge and embrace Yoga to fulfill his duty. This powerful sloka motivates Arjuna to rise and fight, integrating knowledge and action. It encapsulates the chapter’s teachings, emphasizing that Jnana and Karma Yoga together enable Arjuna to overcome hesitation and achieve spiritual victory.
